document.title: Functions of bounded variation and differentiability

para.p:
We say that a function
: f
→ A
∪ R
{ ∞ }
,
⊂ A R
, is increasing if
≤ x y
implies
≤
⁢ F
( x )
⁢ F
( y )
, namely if
f
is order preserving.

Let
< a b
be real. For a function
: F
→
[ a , b ]
R
, define
:
V F
→
[ a , b ]
[ 0 , ∞ ]
by

Math.text: V _ F * x = (supremum _ (list@(N, a) = t _ 0 less t _ 1 less cdots less t _ N = b))@((sum _ j)@(absolute-value@(F * t _ j - F * t _ (j - 1))))

para.p:
called the variation of
F
. It is apparent that
V F
is increasing. If
V F
is bounded, we say that
F
has bounded variation.
V F
being bounded is equivalent to
<
⁢
V F
( b )
∞
. If
F
is increasing then

Math.text: V _ F * x = F * x - F * a

para.p: so in particular an increasing function has bounded variation.

Define
:
P F
→
[ a , b ]
[ 0 , ∞ ]
by

Math.text: P _ F * x = (supremum _ (list@(N, a) = t _ 0 less t _ 1 less cdots less t _ N = b))@((sum _ (F * t _ j >= F * t _ (j - 1)))@(F * t _ j)) - F * t _ (j - 1)

para.p:
called the positive variation of
F
, and define
:
N F
→
[ a , b ]
[ 0 , ∞ ]
by

Math.text: N _ F * x = (supremum _ (list@(N, a) = t _ 0 less t _ 1 less cdots less t _ N = b))@(sum _ (F * t _ j less= F * t _ (j - 1))) - F * t _ j - F * t _ (j - 1)

para.p:
called the negative variation of
F
. It is apparent that
P F
and
N F
are increasing.

We now prove the Jordan decomposition theorem. It shows in particular that if
F
has bounded variation then
P F
and
N F
are bounded.

If
: F
→
[ a , b ]
R
has bounded variation, then for all
∈ x
[ a , b ]
,

Math.text: V _ F * x = P _ F * x + N _ F * x

para.p: and

Math.text: F * x - F * a = P _ F * x - N _ F * x

and as this is true for all

Math.text: F * x - F * a = (sum _ j)@(F * t _ j) - F * t _ (j - 1)
F * x - F * a
absent = (sum _ j)@(F * t _ j) - F * t _ (j - 1)
absent = (sum _ (F * t _ j >= F * t _ (j - 1)))@(F * t _ j) - F * t _ (j - 1) - sum _ (F * t _ j less= F * t _ (j - 1)) - F * t _ j - F * t _ (j - 1)
absent = (sum _ (F * t _ j >= F * t _ (j - 1)))@(F * t _ j) - F * t _ (j - 1) - sum _ (F * t _ j less= F * t _ (j - 1)) - F * t _ j - F * t _ (j - 1)

-

The Jordan decomposition theorem tells us that if
F
has bounded variation then

Math.text: F * x = P _ F * x - F * a - N _ F * x

para.p:
and as
↦ x
-
⁢
P F
( x )
⁢ F
( a )
and
↦ x
⁢
N F
( x )
are increasing, this shows that
F
is the difference of two increasing functions.

The following says that a function of bounded variation is continuous at a point if and only if its variation is continuous at that point. 1 1 footnote 1 V. I. Bogachev, Measure Theory, volume 1, p. 333, Proposition 5.2.2.

If
: F
→
[ a , b ]
R
has bounded variation, then
F
is continuous at
x
if and only if
V F
is continuous at
x
.

If
: F
→
[ a , b ]
R
has bounded variation then there are at most countably many
∈ x
[ a , b ]
at which
F
is not continuous.

We now use the Vitali covering lemma to prove that the Dini derivatives of an increasing function are finite almost everywhere. 4 4 footnote 4 Russell A. Gordon, The Integrals of Lebesgue, Denjoy, Perron, and Henstock, p. 55, Lemma 4.8.
